HypervisorRootCert - to be more clear that its something related to the hypervisor

Just RootCert may be confusing.
Where ever there is VMI -- replace with Hypervisor

There are quite a good amount of errors formatted at https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/redfish-core/src/error_messages.cpp.

I think it's better to use them rather than creating one in all your bad paths.

I'd prefer you didn't.  Those are redfish error codes, in the redfish namespace, and might have to adjust as redfish changes over time.  Also, they point at odata endpoints that this IBM resource doesn't have, so it's nonsensical to return them.  Cross calling error codes between the various protocol types causes weird dependencies between them.

> I'd prefer you didn't.  Those are redfish error codes, in the redfish namespace, and might have to adjust as redfish changes over time.  Also, they point at odata endpoints that this IBM resource doesn't have, so it's nonsensical to return them.  Cross calling error codes between the various protocol types causes weird dependencies between them.

aah, yeah, did not think of it this way. Agree & understood.
Needs update as per the latest DBus path
sure. dbus interfaces are not finalized yet..will update.
Please create a callback for this, rather than continuing down in scope.  This many scopes makes it hard to read.
THis is a blocking call.  See bmcweb rules for why you're not allowed to do this.

Please have a look here where you can create a asynchronus call for the timer and can implemt the same, if you have this requirement.

https://github.ibm.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/1020/redfish-core/lib/certificate_service.hpp#L428

Ratan
already addressed in latest patchset, please take a look
Why are you using the filesystem as a communication mechanism for small entries.  I'm also very confused why bmcweb is responsible for creating this file.  It's a public cert, correct?  Use dbus.

we moved to dbus for sign csr request, hypervisor root certificate will be populated through host interface once hypervisor active, so we just create empty for root certificate and host interface write root certificate to this file. so we though dbus object is not required here.
My preference to use reset,However assignment operator also works.
Don't use res.end() in new code.  Rely on the asyncResp object.
I don't think this was addressed
Is there a good reason to capture it by a different name?
req should not be captured by value, and doesn't appear to be used?
Multiprocessing issue.  ackMatch could be in use at this point.

Ed
i am thinking to add vector of matches to solve this problem.
what do you think?
There's a couple ways to solve this.  I haven't looked deeply enough to know which is the best in this case.
Already addressed this issue using flat_map()
I wonder if ibm console should namespace its directories to avoid conflicts with other bmcweb usages.  Maybe putting within a /ibm_console folder?
In other commit Ed has suggested to use the path as "/var/lib/ibm-console"
This should be created at compile/install time to ensure that it has the proper permissions.

+1, you can do the same in meson.build by calling the meson.add_install_script("create the directory").
https://mesonbuild.com/Installing.html

Ratan
i think we dont need to create directory, backend is already creating.
what do you suggest?
waiting for reviewer's reply on this.

> i think we dont need to create directory, backend is already creating.

Which backend?  Does it have the appropriate permissions?

PLDM creates this folder and updates root certificate while booting host.
Yes it has permissions needed.
I have removed this piece of code as we have come up with D-bus app to host CSR and client certificates.

> PLDM creates this folder and updates root certificate while booting host.

So we're communicating directly BMCWEB->PLDM?  Why aren't the certs written to phosphor-certificate-manager?

yes,actually CSR and client certificate are written to vmi-certificate-manager D-bus app.
only root certificate is placed in this path by pldm and bmcweb reads it.
Root certificate changes only once when host boots.
Don't use res.end() in new code.  Rely on the asyncResp object.
Doesn't point to an odata member.  Not clear why it's included.
This is making an extra copy.
Don't use res.end() in new code.  Rely on the asyncResp object.
Using the redfish version of this is going to return redfish CSDL-based error codes.  Considering ibm console doesn't have any CSDL, that's a little odd.
its followed all over this file, so continued using
So you agree that this as well as all the other redfish CSDL needs to migrate to a non-redfish readJson call?  Or do you plan on implementing CSDL for this endpoint?
This isn't required.  ReadJson will set the appropriate code.
Don't use res.end() in new code.  Rely on the asyncResp object.
Don't use res.end() in new code.  Rely on the asyncResp object.
I guess you still need it because you did not initialize asyncResp
Still would like to see this in an ibm specific root

anyways it will be used in ibm only case right
are looking for something like this "/var/lib/ibm/bmcweb/RootCert"
You should pass shared_ptr instead creating a new one here. Now there are two seperate shared_ptrs that call delete on res, it can cause segfault
nit consider to move it instead of copy
Just FYI, "copy" of a shared_ptr is pretty efficient, so in general we don't worry too much about it.
No response on success. Is it ok?
yes..this method is to delete dbus object after return signed certificate
This doesn't seem like a condition that bmcweb should be checking.  If the service requires a specific host state, it should be in charge of returning the appropriate error code, not bmcweb.

Ed

I understand your point.right, we don't get appropriate error code from backend,
so i thought better to add check here

> Ed
> 
> I understand your point.right, we don't get appropriate error code from backend,
> so i thought better to add check here

Nope, sounds like you need to go fix a bug in the backend, not add more code here.
ok removed host state check here
you use internal_server_error a lot in this code.  Most of the things you've used it for (like this one) are not appropriate, and should instead be using something like bad_request.
in this case server is not in right state to serve this request.
The server (bmcweb) has a state that's fine, the backend is the one that needs to be checking this.
This is not an appropriate way to match an ackMatch with its counterpart.

Ed
i dont think this will be an issue.
say if there are two request almost at same time, the match first appended to vector needs to be removed first( fixed timeout of 5ec)

> Ed
> i dont think this will be an issue.
> say if there are two request almost at same time, the match first appended to vector needs to be removed first( fixed timeout of 5ec)

What if the second request completes before the first?

yes. that will be an issue.
i think std::map with entry id and match will solve this issue
Used flat_map and resolved this issue pointed
Don't use res.end() in new code.

Ed
for some reason, connection is not getting close without this.
i will debug
Please read and understand COMMON_ERRORS.md.  This specific error is called out.
I see ACK, then resolved.  Maybe you meant "Done"?
Don't you need to a check for if this is empty?
i think we can add empty check
Please use a flat_map for this.

Best would be to move it out of this method to avoid any mistake in future. Follow the pattern that every time that AsyncResp is required you create it at the begging of the request method, e.g. line 810

i got your point, most of handlers follow same approach in this file..
i dont see any harm doing this way..

Why it is static? Using static you are using single timer for all requests. So any new request can cancel already used timer. Please, fix it. If you need to prolong life of steady_timer, you can use shared_ptr.
You can get it from crow::connections::systemBus->get_io_context(), you don't have to pass req.
Any reason to copy a req to callback?
You can omit it, csrString is only used as argument to async_method_call
nit You should check if (found + 1) is less than size()

Or, alternatively, help review this patchset, which adds a utility function to the object_path type.

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/sdbusplus/+/39158

have looked this commit, it really helps.
for now adding size check
Need to set a response error here.
Need to check entry exists first with find() and add a debug print..  Otherwise this could fail silently.
Pretty sure this isn't what you intended, that there's no way this code could've worked as-written.

Ed
it works, what's the issue you see here?
basically converting entry id  to string and appending it to object path
this match is for property changed signal on that particular entry

+std::to_string(entryId)

is within the quotes, so you're creating an ack match, but including +std::to_string(entryId), the literal, not actually appending entryId like you intended.
You still need res.end() or make an AsyncResp so .end() will be called in destructor of AsyncResp. Same for other routes. If you omit it you don't get the response
This has no return, and unless I'm mistaken, could've never worked as intended.
Use the other overload of std::filesystem::exists.  This one throws.

There's an effort to simplify this type of operation here:

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/35992


It would help if you review it, even if you don't use it in this patchset.
You might want to avoid using redfish in non-redfish endpoints.
its followed all over the file, will fix in another commit
is it mandatory to avoid in non-redfish endpoints? anyway we are following redfish format os instead of using other utils better to use same one

> is it mandatory to avoid in non-redfish endpoints?

If you are following the redfish format, then it goes in the redfish tree, if you're not following the redfish format, then things should be parsed in the way that makes sense for that implementation.

The problem here is that this function occasionally changes, and the resulting code needs to change.  When an endpoint is backed by the standard, we can say "we're parsing this per the Redfish standard" but given that this code has no specification, returning errors from the redfish tree is kind of nonsensical.

yeah I get your point and completely agree with you.
these redfish::json_util methods used all over this file in multiple places.

Will try to fix all these together in separate commit.
@Gunnar @sunitha what do say?
Why can't we do it here?

do you mean to change in all places in same commit?
I think its good to have new commit to address this as it already used all over file
This check needs to be done in the handling daemon, not in bmcweb.

Ed

this is to avoid large strings entering into bmcweb through this request.
added this check as somebody raised this a security concern

bmcweb should be enforcing the dbus message size limits.  If the server side wants to impose smaller limits than that, it can, and return an appropriate error message.

Written this way, this check would need to be copied into every user-facing daemon (ipmi, bmcweb, etc).

We had discussions about Dbus string sizes on D-bus commit.
yeah I get your point that could have done this check in backend D-bus.
Actually in this use case 4K is max size supported and management console only use this endpoint.

> Actually in this use case 4K is max size supported and management console only use this endpoint.

Great, then please put that in your dbus server, not in bmcweb.

Also, per the dbus design, we assume that in the future there will be other clients and APIs.  The fact that there's only one at this point isn't of concern, as in the future there might be more than one.  bmcweb should be as close to a dbus->REST translator as is possible.

ok, I can do that.
say if there is a large string provided by mistake, 
don't we see any problem if bmcweb trying to place this large string on D-bus?
Seems you wanted to put the check as "if (cert)"

yeah.i wanted to throw error if certificate string is empty,

better to use empty() right?

Ratan is correct.  cert-> will seg fault if cert is not populated, which is in the coding standard, and all code in master follows this rule.  Your new patchset looks correct though, so I'll mark this as resolved.
I am not sure if this is guarantee that status is not nullptr

depends on dbus configuration and dbus traffic your call can stuck for 5 seconds before calling your callback. I know 5 seconds is a lot, but I do not see any reason why do you set it here. Can you move this timer into the callback to avoid racing condition?

yes 5 sec timeout is Max we kept here.
we can move this timer into callback, but i dont think of any race condition
@Jozef: I was not able to understand that how the call can get stuck here, I don't see any blocking call here. However the timer starts at line 752 with the call back as timeout handler.

as written, this code does not appear to do anything.  I see no call to async_wait that would actually start the timer.  Also, in general, for dbus interfaces, we rely on dbus timeouts, were those not sufficient?

This timer needed to close D-bus match and return error to client if host interface does not populate status of this CSR request with in 5 seconds.
normally all these operations are completed in a second.

async_wait called below at 876 line

addressed that comment by modifying above check

 if ((found == std::string::npos) ||
                (found + 1 >= objPath.str.size()))

How we can reach at this condition?
Is it if we get the response before time out occurs and we call the cancel at line no 769?

yeah..we call cancel once we get the response before time out occurs
it will be treated as timer operation aborted.
If the timer gets destroyed before it completes.  This is the same way we handle all other timers.
See comment on other thread.  We do this with all our timer usage.
yeah, This is the same way we handle all other timers.
Can we merge both error cases? If (ec ! =  boost::asio::error::operation_aborted))
i think we need these two check separately.. can't merge
Do you want to delete the Dbus entry also?
yes, deleting d-bus entries. deleteVMIDbusEntry() function called at 671
yes. we need to call deleteVMIDbusEntry() function here as well
I guess you are missing res.end() here. Try to setup first std::shared_ptr<AsyncResp> to avoid missing res.end()
Considering this is for the host, I suspect we shouldn't be writing the cert to a path with bmcweb in it.

Ed 

We have already discussed on this in earlier patch sets and decided to keep it under /ibm/bmcweb/

Do you agree with my reply above?
Waiting for reply on this.

> We have already discussed on this in earlier patch sets and decided to keep it under

Can you link the discussion?  I'm not too worried about this, because it is in the ibm folder, it's just odd that an "IBM" root cert would be localized to bmcweb.  Technically doesn't anything that wants to communicate with the console require access to this?

Also, as a matter of design, aren't root certs supposed to be global to the bmc?  Why isn't this using TrustStore?

Actually this root certificate is populated by Host whenever it boots otherwise it won't change at all and bmcweb is the only app needs to access this file, so created a folder under bmcweb instead of a having separate Dubs-property for root certificate.

please have a look at design doc
https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/designs/management-console/VMI_Certificate_Exchange.md
I agree on the just odd that an "IBM" root cert would be localized to bmcweb
Yes. This path was agreed upon after multiple design considerations.

Memory leak here.

ackMatches[entryId] needs deleted regardless of whether or not this succeeds.

Also, common error #11

do you mean  entryId + "/" ?

how does this make difference.
seems we have multiple instances like this
waiting for reviewer's reply on this

No, I mean escaped using the methods build into sdbusplus::message::object_path.

Escaping/input verification is called out in the bmcweb developing guide.

In this case, it's not a user input, entryId is picked from existing D-bus object.
I think there is no input verification needed here.
Yes. Agree with Ravi. entryId is not a user input here.

Ed, There are some cases

1) one redfish endpoint is built from  one Dbus object
   if we don't find that Dbus resource then return 404

2) one redfish endpoint is built from multiple Dbus object
   If we get the partial data from one Dbus object and was unable to find the other Dbus object
   what should we return there?
   Partial success and then followed by
   Message.ExtendenededInfo for the failures: In the extended info what would be the error message?

Do you agree with the reply above?
Waiting for reply on this.

In the #1 case, yes, 404.

In the #2 case, I'm not following why there's two calls but the rule is:

If a user plugs in a bad input into one of the variable fields (ie, foobar).   It should always return 404.

If we can provide partial results, we should, while setting 500.

If anything breaks the dbus interface contract, it should be omitted.
ok. I think #2 case is not applied in this use-case. Each SignCSR POST request always deals with single CSR.

> If we get the partial data from one Dbus object and was unable to find the other Dbus object



> ok. I think #2 case is not applied in this use-case.

I was keying off the first text.  If there's two dbus objects, I assume we're doing two dbus calls.

I see lots of comments and questions were resolved with just "ACK".  If a question was being asked, please answer it.  If a change was made that makes the comment now irrelevant, or the change was made as the reviewer asked for, please comment that.  "ACK" is meant to mean "I understand this request, but have not made changed it yet" in the context of a patch change.

There are some comments where I am waiting for reviewer's reply, By mistake, marked as Ack.

I just answered a bunch of things.  Some recommendations going forward:

1. Read the documented rules.   Multiple versions of this patchset has broken so many of the documented rules that it makes it much harder to review.
2. If the rules are confusing, ask specific questions on discord if you need a quick response to things.
3. ACK means "I understand and am working on it".  "Done" means "I've made the change asked for".  Being somewhat consistent in these responses helps maintainers to not spend an abnormal amount of time reviewing this.

Please help to review other users code in bmcweb to ensure that everyones patches get done faster.
